message_1: A sample of a radioactive material has an initial activity of 1200 decays per second. After 10 minutes, the activity of the sample drops to 300 decays per second. What is the half-life of the material?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the radioactive decay formula:

A = A0 * (1/2)^(t/T)

where:
A = final activity (300 decays per second)
A0 = initial activity (1200 decays per second)
t = time elapsed (10 minutes = 600 seconds)
T = half-life of the material (which we want to find)

First, we can divide both sides of the equation by A0:

A/A0 = (1/2)^(t/T)

Now, we can plug in the given values:

300/1200 = (1/2)^(600/T)

0.25 = (1/2)^(600/T)

To solve for T, we can take the logarithm of both sides of the equation:

log(0.25) = log((1/2)^(600/T))

log(0.25) = (600/T) * log(1/2)

Now, we can solve for T:

T = 600 * log(1/2) / log(0.25)

T ≈ 600 * (-0.30103) / (-0.60206)

T ≈ 300 seconds

The half-life of the radioactive material is approximately 300 seconds.
